etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French briber, brimber ‘beg’, of unknown origin. The original sense was ‘rob, extort’, hence (as a noun) ‘theft, stolen goods’, also ‘money extorted or demanded for favors’, later ‘offer money as an inducement’ (early 16th century)

definitions: persuade (someone) to act in one's favor, typically illegally or dishonestly, by a gift of money or other inducement

examples.text: an undercover agent bribed the judge into giving a lenient sentence
you weren't willing to be good to your sister without being bribed with a lollipop
he has no money to bribe with

shortDefinitions: dishonestly persuade someone to act in one's favour by gift of money

definitions: a sum of money or other inducement offered or given to bribe someone

examples.text: lawmakers were caught accepting bribes to bring in legalized gambling

shortDefinitions: sum of money or other inducement
